_prev_prog_2.FR_Comments: Utilize MDA forms for maintenance inspections on equipment
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: piping, vales, pumps, storage tanks, nurse tanks, etc.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Central Farm Service 
233 West Ciro Street
PO Box 68
Truman, MN 56088
Risk Management Plan - EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at the Facility:

The Coop board, management and employees at Central Farm Service, Bricelyn, MN location, are committed to the prevention of accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, and all other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.

2. Facility Information and Regulated Substance:

The primary activity at the facility is the storage of fertilizers for sale to farmers. Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, handled and distributed for direct application. Anhydrous ammonia is used for crop production nutrients.

The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia would be approximately 200,000 pounds in our two 12,000 and one 18,000 gallon storage tanks; and approximately 120,000 pounds available capacity in various nurse tanks ranging in capacity from 1,000 gallons to 1,450 gallons. The maximum quantity handled at one time would be the unloading of a tank truck holding 40,000-45,000 pounds.

This facility is not constantly manned every work day.  There are approximately six employees who may work on the site periodically throughout the year, computing to one employee on site part-time.  At a minimum, the site would have a daily visual check. 

3. General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:

The facility has implemented Minnesota Dept. of Agriculture rules, the Standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia; and 40 CFR part 68 as they apply to this facility. The facility is required to conduct a semi-annual inspection of all bulk and nurse tank equipment, including load and unload eq

uipment, and perform any needed maintenance to the equipment found during the inspections. Visual checks are to be conducted daily at the
facility.

4. The Five-year Accident History:  

There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that have: 

a) Caused any death, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; or 
b) To our knowledge resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage.

5. The Emergency Response Program.

The facility has:

a. A written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.38 and 40 CFR 68.95.  The plan includes a specific section on NH3 Releases and what to do in the event of a release. The next annual emergency action plan training is scheduled for July 2014. Additional emergency response training is also provided throughout the year at various training sessions, including but not limited to a training session just on anhydrous ammonia held every fall.  

b. Provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA);

c. Coordinated with local emergency responders.

d. A Safety Data Sheet for anhydrous ammonia as part of their emergency response plan information for quick access and reference.

e. A Minnesota AWAIR (A Workplace Accident and Injury Reduction) program in place and is committed to a safe working environment as well as protection of the community in which we operate.
